titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. In Senate— The subject debated was upon the second reading of one of the bills creating the Stock, for the payments required by the Louisiana Treaty.— A proviso at the close of the first Section appeared to me to sanction a departure from the terms of the Convention, and to remove the possibility of any such imputation in future, I moved to insert the words “with the assent of the French Government.”— Mr: Taylor of Virginia moved another amendment to the same proviso— They lay over for consideration to-morrow— But Mr: Wright was against every amendment that could possibly be proposed to the bill; because it was drawn up by the Secretary of the Treasury, who could better legislate for us on this subject than we can do congressionally.— What will become of Mr: Taylor’s amendment I know not— Mine will certainly not pass— And indeed I have already seen enough to ascertain that no amendments of my proposing will obtain in the Senate as now filled— Nor was this State of things, at all unexpected to me— The qualities of mind most peculiarly called for under it, are firmness, perseverance, patience, coolness and forbearance— The prospect is not promising.— Yet the part to act may be as honourably performed, as if success could attend it— We adjourned soon after two.

2. The debate on the bill creating 11250000 dollars of 6 per ct: Stock was continued, and an amendment comprizing Mr: Taylor’s proposed amendment and mine finally agreed to— Mr: Wright explained away what he said yesterday about the Secretary of the Treasury’s drawing up the bill &c.— It pass’d to the third reading, after the rejection of a motion from Mr: Wright to postpone the subject untill the second Monday in December, to know whether the possession of New-Orleans will be given.— The other bill, providing for the payment of the claims, four millions, pass’d the third reading.— Adjourned 1/2 past two— Received a letter from my mother.— Read this Evening to the Ladies a new play of Colman’ s— “John Bull, or the Englishman’s fire-side.”

3. Had a very long debate in Senate on the passage of the act creating eleven millions of Stock— The question was finally taken by yeas and nays— 26 yeas 5 nays.— I voted in favour of this bill.— Read part of a play this Evening to the Ladies— The marriage promise— But it was so bad I could not finish it.

4. In Senate— Debate upon the Convention of limits, with Great-Britain, dated 12. May last.— Mr: Butler withdrew his motion for an amendment— Mr: Wright urged the objection, on account of the possible interference between this Treaty, and that containing the cession of Louisiana— Subject further postponed untill next Monday— Mr: Butler’s proposed Resolution for a new Negotiation with France, was resumed and negatived— He then called up the Resolution pass’d by the House of Representatives relative to the future elections of President and Vice-President, and the majority manifesting an aversion to taking it up, he called upon them for their reasons— When the subject was before the Senate before, he said, they were for hurrying the measure with extreme precipitation; it was with the utmost difficulty that he could obtain one day for consideration. He wished to know the reasons why that excessive haste had now given place to the indifference, and studied delay of the present time— He meant therefore to call it up every day; and demand the yeas and nays, every time he should call it up, untill some reason should be given for the neglect it now meets with— He was only answered, that every Gentleman had his own reasons, for voting as he pleased, and was not obliged to give them— A large majority determined against taking it up.— The reason is that they could not carry the vote by the Constitutional majority now; and wait for the arrival of the member from New-York who will come instead of Mr: Clinton; the return of Mr: S. Smith who is absent; and the arrival of General Sumpter from South-Carolina.— Adjourned at 2. to Monday Morning— The Editor of the National Intelligencer S. H. Smith came to me, and desired me to give him the substance of what I said on the debate yesterday, for publication; as other Gentlemen on both sides of the question had promised him they would— I agreed to furnish him with it.

5. Detained at home the whole day by rain— Read the documents and correspondence, sent to the senate with the Louisiana Treaty— Mr: Pichon called and visited me this morning, and Mr: Madison, just before dinner— Pichon appears to be surprized at the opposition raised by Spain against this cession; and feels some irritation with the Marquis de Casa Yrujo, the Spanish Minister here, who he thinks, in his letters to his Government, stimulates their jealousies against the United States.

6. The rain during the greatest part of this day detained me at home. I wrote, all the forenoon— After dinner read a couple of Mr: Hewlett’s Sermons, and in the Evening Plutarch’s lives of Themistocles and Camillus— The weather clearing up towards the Evening, I walk’d out— Cold at Night.

7. In Senate— Met Mr: Tracy and Mr: Baldwin, on a Committee to whom was referred a bill making an appropriation of 50,000 dollars, to carry into effect the 7th: Article of the Treaty with Great-Britain, of Novr: 1794. Postponed the report to consult the Secretary of the Treasury, on a question occurring from the bill— No business of consequence was done in Senate; and they adjourned early, untill Thursday, to give time for the workmen to repair the cieling, which is ruinous— Another motive, not mentioned might be, that the annual horse-races of the City are held this week.— After the adjournment, I called upon the Secretary of the Treasury and consulted with him, on the appropriation bill; upon which he gave me the information desired. I also conversed with him respecting the
settlement of my accounts, in which I presume all the difficulties are now removed— I called at the Auditor’s Office, but he was not there.— Dined with my wife at the President’s— The company were 17 in number— Mr: Madison, his lady and her Sister— Mr: Wright and his two daughters, and Miss Gray— Mr: Butler and General M’Pherson of Philadelphia were there— Also Mr: Eppes and Mr: Randolph, Mr: Jefferson’s two sons in Law, and both members of the House of Representatives.— After dinner, Mr: Macon the Speaker of the House, and Mr: John Randolph and Mr: Venables came in— We came home at about 6.

8. I called this morning and paid a visit to Mr: Butler, Senator from South-Carolina, whom I found with his three daughters— Mr: Anderson of Tennessee was also there— Went afterwards with my wife, Caroline, Harriet and T. B. Johnson to the race— We went soon after eleven o’clock, and waited nearly three hours before they began.— In less than an hour they were over, and we returned home to dinner— I have never seen regular horce-races before.

9. Second day of the Races; but I did not attend them— Called at the Office of the Auditor of the Treasury, but he was not there. I went up to the Capitol, and into the Library; where I found Mr: Davenport. Left Cards for Mr: Otis, Mr: Baldwin, Mr: Bailey, Mr: Bradley and Genl: Jackson, at their lodgings. Called also on Mr: Tracy, where I found Mr: Plumer and Mr: Chamberlin— Came home not long before four.— Read Plutarch’s life of Fabius Maximus.

10. Attended at the Senate chamber, and found they had adjourned before I arrived— Collected some volumes of old Journals— In the evening, went with the Ladies to the ball which was excessively crowded— It was one in the morning before we came home.— Mr: Condit’s credentials read

11. The Senate sat about an hour and adjourned to Monday next— Mr: Worthington presented the Resolutions of the Legislature of the State of Ohio, in favour of an Amendment in the Constitution relative to the mode of electing a President and Vice-President— Mr: Bradley had yesterday presented similar Resolutions from Vermont.— By direction of the Committee I reported the bill referred to us, without amendment. It was read the second time, and pass’d to a third reading. Soon after the adjournment I returned home, and wrote untill dinner time— Read Plutarch’s life of Alcibiades, and in the Evening to the Ladies a play called the Voice of Nature.— Very indifferent.— Mr: Clinton’s notice of Resignation read— 4 Novr. dated.— I saw the Auditor at his office.

12. Spent the day at home, chiefly employed in perusing and analyzing the correspondence upon the Louisiana Treaty— Read Plutarch’s life of Coriolanus; and some other things— Before dinner I walk’d round into Georgetown.

13. I went to meeting at Georgetown, and heard Mr: Balch in the morning— Very thinly attended: the weather was indeed cold and rainy— Afterwards paid a visit to Mr: Pichon, and to Mr: F. Deakins— Pichon expects a continental War in Europe— The leisure part of the day I employed in writing.

14. In Senate, where we had a very warm debate on the question, for taking up the Resolution for an Amendment of the Constitution— The motion was negatived, and the reason finally avowed— It was sometime after three when the adjournment took place.— Dined, with Mrs: Johnson, Mr: and Mrs: Hellen, and my wife, at Mr: F. Deakins’s.— A company of about 20 to dinner, and of more than fifty in the Evening. Mr: T. Lewis a member of Congress from Virginia was here first introduced to me— Mr: Huger was very sociable.

15. In Senate— Executive business— The Convention of limits with England, committed to a select Committee— Four indian Treaties— Mr: Breckenridge offered a resolution for their ratification. Nominations acted upon; some postponed— Adjourned after 2.— I went home with Mr: Cranch, and borrowed of him the 2 volumes of the Federalist— Evening at home.

16. In Senate; on motion of Mr: Wright, the resolutions for amending the Constitution, in the Article of the Presidential election, was made the order of the day for next Monday— The advice and consent of the Senate was given to the four Indian Treaties— Unanimously.— Adjourned, after two— Wrote my brother. Tea and pass’d the evening at Dr: Thornton’s— Company numerous of Ladies and Gentlemen— Had some conversation with Mr: Madison.

17. Met Mr: John Smith of Ohio, and walk’d with him to the Senate chamber— The Senate did but little business, and adjourned early— I called upon the Auditor at the Treasury, to see if was ready with my accounts; but he was not— Called also on Mr: Madison, who does not approve the Resolution for the conditional ratification of the Treaty— Mr: Nicholas had been with him— Mrs: Adams very ill this afternoon with a severe sick head ache— I was quite unwell myself with a bad cold—

18. Mrs: Adams much better; my own cold also less troublesome— Attended in Senate— Bill for declaring War against the Emperor of Morocco— Mr: Dayton moved it should be read a second time on this day— Unanimous Consent was necessary; and I alone objected— My principle was that a declaration of War, was the last thing in the world to be made with unusual precipitation— Executive business— The whole day spent in a debate about Abraham Bishop— Adjourned after 3. O’Clock— Evening at home— I am reading the Federalist.

19. I called at the Office of the Secretary of State, but Mr: Madison was not there— Walk’d over to Georgetown— Called at March’s— Remainder of the day at home writing very assiduously, to little purpose— Our youngest child very unwell this Evening.
20. Visits from Mr: Dalton, Genl: Dearborn, &c— All day at home writing assiduously.

21. In Senate— On a bill from the House of Representatives, equivalent to a Declaration of War, against the Emperor of Morocco— Mr: Wright moved the addition of a clause recognizing the principle that free ships make free goods, which was debated untill almost 3. o’clock when the Senate adjourned— Took from the library the first volume of Raynal’s History of the East and West-Indies— Of which I read the introduction to the Ladies in the Evening— Dr: Coats, a brother in Law, of Mr: Murray, brought me a letter from him, and Mr: Elwin an Englishman brought one from my brother, which they delivered me, in the midst of the debate.

22. In Senate— Mr: Wright made a speech of one hour long, upon the question discussed yesterday, concerning his amendment— His colleague Mr: S. Smith suggested the necessity of some other amendments to the bill, upon which it was committed to Mr: S. Smith, Mr: Jackson and myself— The Resolutions for amending the Constitution were taken up— Mr: Dayton made his motion for abolishing the Office of Vice-President— Mr: Taylor argued from the words in the Constitution that amendments may be adopted whenever two thirds of both houses agree to them— A Question was made by Mr: Bradley, whether incidental questions upon alterations in proposed amendments to the Constitution must be decided by two thirds or only by a majority. The President doubted— Precedents were looked for— And the subject postponed— Executive business. Several nominations, confirmed— One among the rest of a man stated by Mr: Franklin to be dead.nominated as one of the Judges for the district of Columbia, instead of James Marshall resigned— Dined with our Ladies at Mr: Pichon’s— Mr: R. Smith, Messrs: Dayton, Wells and White, and Mr and Mrs: Huger there— Dr: Thornton and his Lady there in the Evening.

23. In Senate. Met Genl: Smith and Genl: Jackson in Committee before the Senate assembled— We agreed to report several Sections proposed by Genl: Smith, and disagreed to the amendment proposed— The report was made and is to be printed— Debated the proposed Amendment to the Constitution, on a question of order, untill the adjournment, after 3 O’Clock— Read in Raynal, this Evening, to the Ladies.

24. In Senate— I went rather late, and found them on the debate for the constitutional Amendment; which continued untill past 3.— The question, upon an incidental debate not material to the quest main principle— Debates warm— Read to the ladies in the Evening.

25. The debate on the Constitutional question was postponed on account of Mr: Anderson’s absence— The bill for hostilities against Morocco, pass’d to the third reading— Sundry other business of less importance— After the adjournment, met Mr: Nicholas and Mr: Wright in the Committee on the Treaty of limits with Great-Britain— They directed me to report a postponement to the 20th: of February.— I called this morning on Mr: Madison, and had some conversation with him— I laid a motion on the table for the appointment of a Committee to inquire into the necessity of further measures to carry into effect the Louisiana Treaty. At home this Evening, and read in Raynal.

26. I called again at the Auditor’s Office, for the settlement of my accounts; but Mr: Harrison was not there, and some new difficulties have been started, which I am still to remove— We dined at Mr: Madison’s, with a large Company of Ladies and Gentlemen— We were there also great part of the Evening.

27. Heard a preacher, whose name I did not know, at the Treasury Office.— Afterwards paid visits to Genl: Dearborn, Secretary at War, Coll: Burrows, Mr: R. Smith, Secretary of the Navy, Mr: and Mrs: Morton, and Mr: and Mrs: Payne. Read in the Evening, in Raynal, to some of the Ladies.

28. In Senate. The Amendment to the Constitution was again postponed on account of Mr: Anderson’s absence; he is unwell— Mr: Wright gave up his amendment to the Morocco bill. He laid a resolution on the table, for appointing a Committee to make a form or forms of Government for Louisiana.

29. Bankrupt Law at the second reading— Motion to commit rejected— Made the order of the day to-morrow. Had up the proposed amendment to the Constitution— I called for the yeas and nays on the question for 3 or 5. Spoken in favour of 5 and against 3— in vain— For 5. Yeas 12. Nays 19.— For 3. Yeas 21. nays 10.— Adjourned about 4.— In the morning I called upon Mr: Elwin.

30. Mr: Taylor determined to take the final question on the Amendment this day; as Mr: Condit was obliged to go away to-morrow— But after debating untill 4 o’clock it was found impossible— Mr: Condit agreed to stay to-morrow; and the question is adjourned untill then— A company of ladies and Gentlemen dined with us at Mr: Hellen’s— There was also Company invited for the evening; but they were prevented by stormy weather from coming.

Day— Rise at about 7. write until 10. Breakfast— Walk to the Senate, where I attend untill the adjournment; usually between 3 and 4. Return home and dine immediately— Sit about an hour after dinner, and spent the Evening in reading; either in my chamber or to the Ladies— Sup at 10 and go to bed about 11.— On Sundays attend public worship when I can; and pay or receive visits.
